content: Many governments recognize the international risks of environmental degradation and climate change, leading to negotiations for agreements to protect the environment and promote sustainable growth. Efforts by wealthier countries alone are deemed insufficient without similar measures in lower-income countries prioritizing poverty reduction. International financial assistance is crucial for lower-income countries to address global environmental problems. The UNFCCC, ratified by the United States in 1992, was the first treaty to acknowledge human-driven climate change. The UNFCCC, ratified by the United States in 1992, requires higher-income Parties to provide financial resources to developing countries for meeting their climate change obligations. The UNFCCC requires developed countries to provide financial resources to developing countries for climate change obligations. The United States has provided assistance through various programs to support developing countries in addressing climate change. The United States provides bilateral and multilateral assistance for climate change through various programs and international financial institutions. The UNFCCC establishes a financial mechanism to provide climate finance to developing countries through various international entities like the GCF, UNDP, UNEP, World Bank's Climate Investment Funds, and the Forest Carbon Partnership Facility. The GEF, established in 1991, is an official operating entity of the financial mechanism. The GEF, established in 1991, is an official operating entity of the financial mechanism under the UNFCCC.
